definition: lit. to like the new, and hate the old (idiom); fig. enamored with new people (e.g. new girlfriend), bored with the old
to be fond of/to like/to enjoy/to be happy/to feel pleased/happiness/delight/glad
abbr. for Xinjiang 新疆[Xin1 jiang1] or Singapore 新加坡[Xin1 jia1 po1]/surname Xin
new/newly/meso- (chemistry)
to loathe
old/opposite: new 新/former/worn (with age)

sentences.english: Nothing gets old as fast as the future.
sentences.chinese: 未来喜新厌旧的速度无与伦比。

definition: to change at once on seeing sth different (idiom); loving fads and novelty/never satisfied with what one has
lit. say three in the morning but four in the evening (idiom); to change sth that is already settled upon/indecisive/to blow hot and cold
fickle/mercurial/changeable/capricious/to be apt to change
see 懷舊|怀旧[huai2 jiu4]
fickle in love/sentimentality
change of affection, shift of love (idiom); to change one's feelings to another love/to fall in love with sb else
to cease to be faithful
faithful unto death (i.e. Confucian ban on widow remarrying)
fickle (in love affairs)/dissipated/unfaithful/heart of a flower (pistil and stamen)
to remember old friends/to cherish old friendships/for old time's sake
to seek happiness elsewhere (euphemism for extramarital sex)/a bit on the side
inconstant in love/fickle
(coll.) womanizer/skirt-chaser
vain
brief period of enthusiasm/flash in the pan
single-minded/concentrated
